item.gloss: Witness: a godparent usually associated with the puritan tradition, which saw the role of godparents as being quite restricted. While Thomas Comber used the term interchangeably with others, including ‘godparent’, in his Brief Discourse Upon the Offices of Baptism and Confirmation (1675), Thornton changed her vocabulary from the 1650s to the 1660s. See David Cressy, Birth, Marriage and Death: Ritual, Religion, and the Life-Cycle in Tudor and Stuart England (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 1997), 152.
Nonage: ‘The state of being under full legal age; minority', OEDO.
Prove: 'test', OEDO.
Amain: ‘immediately’, OEDO.
Iniquities: 'Unrighteous acts or doings, sins; wrongful acts, injuries', OEDO.
Surfeit: 'Illness attributed to excessive eating or drinking (or, occasionally, to extremes of temperature)', OEDO.
Measles: 'various diseases causing a red rash', OEDO. See Alan Dyer, ‘Epidemics of Measles in a Seventeenth Century English Town’, Local Population Studies 34 (1985): 35–45.

Daily psalms for the month: the Book of Common Prayer outlines how to read through the whole book of Psalms, setting Psalms to be read morning and evening each day. See The Book of Common Prayer: The Texts of 1549, 1559, and 1662, ed. Brian Cummings (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 2011), 185, 219.
Incomprehensible: ‘That cannot be contained or circumscribed within limits; illimitable, boundless’, OEDO.
Sweet: ‘Pleasant disposition and manners’, OEDO.
Quality: 'A personal attribute, a trait, a feature of a person's character’, OEDO.
Quality: ‘Rank … in society’, OEDO.

Salvation: 'The saving of the soul; the deliverance from sin and its consequences, and admission to eternal bliss, wrought for man by the atonement of Christ', OEDO. On protestantism and salvation, see Alec Ryrie, Being Protestant in Reformation Britain (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 2013), chap. 2.
Painful: 'Of an action, occupation, etc.:performed with or involving great care or diligence', OEDO.
Cordial: 'Heartfelt, hearty; sincere, genuine; thoroughly committed to a course of action or a cause', OEDO.

Providence: 'The foreknowing and protective care of God (or nature, etc.); divine direction, control, or guidance', OEDO. See Alexandra Walsham, Providence in Early Modern England (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 1999).
Stone: ‘A hard morbid concretion in the body, esp. in the kidney or urinary bladder, or in the gallbladder’, OEDO.
Shipman: ‘A seaman or sailor’, OEDO.
Sweetly: ‘smoothly, easily’, OEDO.
Surfeit: 'Illness attributed to excessive eating or drinking (or, occasionally, to extremes of temperature)', OEDO.
Physic: 'A medicinal substance', OEDO.
Pleurisy: 'an abscess of the ribs or inner surface of the chest’, OEDO. See Adrian Wilson, ‘On the History of Disease-Concepts: The Case of Pleurisy’, History of Science 38, no. 3 (2000): 271–319.
Wath: 'A ford; a fordable stream', OEDO.
Ague: 'An acute or high fever; disease, or a disease, characterized by such fever, esp. when recurring periodically’, OEDO.
Jaundice: 'A morbid condition caused by obstruction of the bile, and characterized by yellowness’, OEDO.

Witness: a godparent usually associated with the puritan tradition, which saw the role of godparents as being quite restricted. While Thomas Comber used the term interchangeably with others, including ‘godparent’, in his Brief Discourse Upon the Offices of Baptism and Confirmation (1675), Thornton changed her vocabulary from the 1650s to the 1660s. See David Cressy, Birth, Marriage and Death: Ritual, Religion, and the Life-Cycle in Tudor and Stuart England (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 1997), 152.

Witness: a godparent usually associated with the puritan tradition, which saw the role of godparents as being quite restricted. While Thomas Comber used the term interchangeably with others, including ‘godparent’, in his Brief Discourse Upon the Offices of Baptism and Confirmation (1675), Thornton changed her vocabulary from the 1650s to the 1660s. See David Cressy, Birth, Marriage and Death: Ritual, Religion, and the Life-Cycle in Tudor and Stuart England (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 1997), 152.

Witness: a godparent usually associated with the puritan tradition, which saw the role of godparents as being quite restricted. While Thomas Comber used the term interchangeably with others, including ‘godparent’, in his Brief Discourse Upon the Offices of Baptism and Confirmation (1675), Thornton changed her vocabulary from the 1650s to the 1660s. See David Cressy, Birth, Marriage and Death: Ritual, Religion, and the Life-Cycle in Tudor and Stuart England (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 1997), 152.
Ague: 'An acute or high fever; disease, or a disease, characterized by such fever, esp. when recurring periodically’, OEDO.
Jaundice: 'A morbid condition caused by obstruction of the bile, and characterized by yellowness’, OEDO.
Travail: 'childbirth; labour’, OEDO.
Consumption: 'abnormality or loss of humours, resulting in wasting', OEDO.

Salvation: ‘The saving of the soul; the deliverance from sin and its consequences, and admission to eternal bliss, wrought for man by the atonement of Christ', OEDO. On protestantism and salvation, see Alec Ryrie, Being Protestant in Reformation Britain (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 2013), chap. 2.
Stitch: 'A sharp sudden local pain’, OEDO.
Phlegm: 'one of the four cardinal humours … described as cold and moist', OEDO.

Sanctification: ’The action of the Holy Spirit in sanctifying or making holy the believer, by the implanting within him of the Christian graces and the destruction of sinful affections. Also, the condition or process of being so sanctified', OEDO.
Sweet: ‘Dearly loved or prized, precious’, OEDO.
Chiefest: 'At the head or top in importance;most important, influential', OEDO.
Quire: ‘an area in a church, abbey, monastery, etc., reserved for a particular group to use’, OEDO.
Diuretic: ‘A substance having the property of promoting excretion or evacuation of urine’, OEDO.
Goodly: 'Of good or pleasing appearance', OEDO.

Surety: 'A godparent', OEDO. This terminology – rather than godparent – was used by protestants and those wishing to distance themselves from what was seen as popish practices, especially during the religious upheavals of the 1640s and 1650s. See David Cressy, Birth, Marriage and Death: Ritual, Religion, and the Life-Cycle in Tudor and Stuart England (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 1997), 152.
Sennight: ‘A period of seven successive days and nights; a week’, OEDO.
Sweetly: ‘In a desirable or satisfactory way’, OEDO.
Droil: 'Drudgery; toil in disagreeable work', OEDO.
Cordial: ‘A food or (esp. alcoholic) drink with medicinal or health-giving properties’, OEDO.
Cross: ‘misfortune, adversity, OEDO.
Sweet: ‘Gentle, easy’, OEDO.
Trinity: 'The three “persons” or modes of being of the Godhead as conceived in orthodox Christian belief; the Father, Son, and Holy Spirit as constituting one God', OEDO.
Trinity: 'The three “persons” or modes of being of the Godhead as conceived in orthodox Christian belief; the Father, Son, and Holy Spirit as constituting one God', OEDO.

Salvation: ‘Salvation: 'The saving of the soul; the deliverance from sin and its consequences, and admission to eternal bliss, wrought for man by the atonement of Christ', OEDO. On protestantism and salvation, see Alec Ryrie, Being Protestant in Reformation Britain (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 2013), chap. 2.
Sweetly: 'With graciousness of action or treatment; with kindly disposition or intent; graciously', OEDO.
Sweet: ‘Gentle, easy’, OEDO.
Sweet: ‘Dearly loved or prized, precious’, OEDO.
Quick with child: 'Pregnant with a live fetus', OEDO.
Extremity: 'Extreme or inordinate intensity or violence (of passion, action, suffering, labour, etc)', OEDO.
Plaster: 'A solid medicinal or emollient substance spread on a bandage or dressing and applied to the skin, often becoming adhesive at body temperature', OEDO.
Steer: 'A young ox, esp. one which has been castrated', OEDO.
Steer: 'A young ox, esp. one which has been castrated', OEDO.
Draft: 'A team of horses or other beasts of draught, together with that which they draw', OEDO. Here the latter.
Steer: 'A young ox, esp. one which has been castrated', OEDO.
Martinmas: '(The date of) the feast of St Martin, 11 November', OEDO.

Bond: 'A deed, by which A (known as the obligor) binds himself or herself, his or her heirs, executors, or assigns to pay a certain sum of money to B (known as the obligee), or his or her heirs, etc.', OEDO.
Executor: 'A person appointed by a testator to execute or carry into effect his or her will after his or her decease', OEDO.
Michaelmas: 'The feast of St Michael (St Michael and all Angels), one of the quarter days in England, Ireland, and Wales; the date of this, 29 September', OEDO.

Bond: 'A deed, by which A (known as the obligor) binds himself or herself, his or her heirs, executors, or assigns to pay a certain sum of money to B (known as the obligee), or his or her heirs, etc.', OEDO.
Passion: ‘Intense anger; rage; temper’, OEDO.
Grief: ‘A morbid affection of any part of the body; a sore, wound’, OEDO.
Worm: 'A human being likened to a worm or reptile as an object of contempt, scorn, or pity; an abject, miserable creature', OEDO.
Lord (God) of Hosts: ‘a frequent title of Jehovah in certain books of the Old Testament; apparently referring sometimes to the heavenly hosts...sometimes to the armies of Israel', OEDO.
Remark: ‘A sign, mark, indication of something notable’, OEDO.
Grief: ‘Mental pain, distress, or sorrow’, OEDO.
Execution: ‘the seizure of the goods or person of a debtor in default of payment', OEDO.
Assignment: 'Legal transference of a right or property', OEDO.
Portion: 'The part or share of an estate given or passing by law to an heir or other beneficiary, or to be distributed to an heir in the settlement of the estate', OEDO.
Execution: 'the seizure of the goods or person of a debtor in default of payment', OEDO.
Bailiff: 'An officer of justice under a sheriff, who executes writs and processes, distrains, and arrests', OEDO.
Plate: 'Gold or silver vessels and utensils', OEDO.
Plate: 'Gold or silver vessels and utensils', OEDO.
Grief: ‘Hardship, suffering; a kind, or cause, of hardship or suffering’, OEDO.
Redound: 'contributing to some advantage or disadvantage for a person or thing', OEDO.
Quick goods: 'Quick or live animals, livestock', Yorkshire Historical Dictionary, https://yorkshiredictionary.york.ac.uk/words/quick%20goods.
Portion: 'The part or share of an estate given or passing by law to an heir or other beneficiary, or to be distributed to an heir in the settlement of the estate', OEDO.
Bailiff: 'An officer of justice under a sheriff, who executes writs and processes, distrains, and arrests', OEDO.
Apprehension: ‘The action of “feeling” anything emotionally; sensitiveness’, OEDO.

Salvation: 'The saving of the soul; the deliverance from sin and its consequences, and admission to eternal bliss, wrought for man by the atonement of Christ', OEDO. On protestantism and salvation, see Alec Ryrie, Being Protestant in Reformation Britain (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 2013), chap. 2.
Quickened: ‘Made living or lively; animated, revived, stimulated’, OEDO.

Salvation: 'The saving of the soul; the deliverance from sin and its consequences, and admission to eternal bliss, wrought for man by the atonement of Christ', OEDO. On protestantism and salvation, see Alec Ryrie, Being Protestant in Reformation Britain (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 2013), chap. 2.
Temporals: 'Temporal things or matters', OEDO.
Trinity: 'The three “persons” or modes of being of the Godhead as conceived in orthodox Christian belief; the Father, Son, and Holy Spirit as constituting one God', OEDO.
Settlement: 'The act of settling property upon a person or persons', OEDO.
Article: ‘Each of the distinct heads or points of an agreement or treaty. Chiefly in plural: a set of these points comprising a formal agreement’, OEDO.
Strait: ‘Of fortune, means, circumstances: Limited so as to cause hardship or inconvenience; inadequate’, OEDO.
Fine: 'An agreement, a contract, esp. (in early use) a marriage contract', OEDO.
Portion: 'The part or share of an estate given or passing by law to an heir or other beneficiary, or to be distributed to an heir in the settlement of the estate', OEDO.
Article: ‘Each of the distinct heads or points of an agreement or treaty. Chiefly in plural: a set of these points comprising a formal agreement (frequently with of)’, OEDO.

Bond: 'A deed, by which A (known as the obligor) binds himself or herself, his or her heirs, executors, or assigns to pay a certain sum of money to B (known as the obligee), or his or her heirs, etc.', OEDO.
Portion: 'The part or share of an estate given or passing by law to an heir or other beneficiary, or to be distributed to an heir in the settlement of the estate', OEDO.
Settlement: 'The act of settling property upon a person or persons', OEDO.
Temporal: ‘Secular as opposed to sacred’, OEDO.
Equity: ‘What is fair and right’, OEDO.
Sweet: ‘Dearly loved or prized, precious’, OEDO.
Travail: 'childbirth; labour’, OEDO.
Flood: 'A popular term for uterine hæmorrhage, esp. in connection with parturition', OEDO.
Flux: ‘An abnormally copious flowing of blood’, OEDO.
Candlemas: 'The feast of the purification of the Virgin Mary (or presentation of Christ in the Temple) celebrated with a great display of candles', OEDO. This is celebrated on 2 February.
Worm: 'A human being likened to a worm or reptile as an object of contempt, scorn, or pity; an abject, miserable creature', OEDO.
Temporal: ‘Secular as opposed to sacred’, OEDO.
Trinity: 'The three “persons” or modes of being of the Godhead as conceived in orthodox Christian belief; the Father, Son, and Holy Spirit as constituting one God', OEDO.
Competency: ‘A sufficient supply; a sufficiency of’, OEDO.
Posterity: 'The descendants collectively of any person (or, in extended use, any living thing); all who are descended from a common ancestor', OEDO.
Temporal: ‘Secular as opposed to sacred’, OEDO.
Temporals: 'Temporal things or matters', OEDO.
Remembering: ‘That … reminds’, OEDO. Adj.
Travail: 'childbirth; labour’, OEDO.
Goodly: 'Of good or pleasing appearance', OEDO.
Sweet: ‘Dearly loved or prized, precious’, OEDO.
Flood: 'A popular term for uterine hæmorrhage, esp. in connection with parturition', OEDO.
Extremity: 'Extreme or inordinate intensity or violence (of passion, action, suffering, labour, etc)', OEDO.
Incomprehensible: ‘That cannot be contained or circumscribed within limits; illimitable, boundless’, OEDO.
Wretch: ‘one of opprobrious or reprehensible character; a mean or contemptible creature’, OEDO.

Salvation: ‘The saving of the soul; the deliverance from sin and its consequences, and admission to eternal bliss, wrought for man by the atonement of Christ’, OEDO. On protestantism and salvation, see Alec Ryrie, Being Protestant in Reformation Britain (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 2013), chap. 2.
Sweet: ‘Dearly loved or prized, precious’, OEDO.
Temporal: ‘Secular as opposed to sacred’, OEDO.
Peradventure: ‘perhaps, maybe, possibly’, OEDO.

Providence: 'The foreknowing and protective care of God (or nature, etc.); divine direction, control, or guidance', OEDO. See Alexandra Walsham, Providence in Early Modern England (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 1999).
Distemper: 'Derangement or disturbance of the “humour” or “temper”', OEDO.
Distemper: 'Derangement or disturbance of the “humour” or “temper” ', OEDO.
Palsy: 'Paralysis or paresis (weakness) of all or part of the body, sometimes with tremor’, OEDO.
Convulsion: 'An involuntary contraction, stiffening, or “drawing up” of a muscle, limb, etc.', OEDO.
High: ‘Great, or greater than normal, in amount, level, size, or intensity; extreme; strong, forcible, violent’, OEDO.
Grief: ‘Mental pain, distress, or sorrow’, OEDO.
Extremity: 'Extreme or inordinate intensity or violence (of passion, action, suffering, labour, etc)', OEDO.
Temporal: ‘Secular as opposed to sacred’, OEDO.
Trinity: 'The three “persons” or modes of being of the Godhead as conceived in orthodox Christian belief; the Father, Son, and Holy Spirit as constituting one', OEDO.
Discomforted: ‘deprive of courage or strength of mind; to discourage, dishearten, dismay', OEDO.

Providence: 'The foreknowing and protective care of God (or nature, etc.); divine direction, control, or guidance', OEDO. See Alexandra Walsham, Providence in Early Modern England (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 1999).
Peradventure: ‘Expressing a hypothetical, contingent or uncertain possibility:perhaps, maybe, possibly', OEDO.
Vouchsafe: ‘show a gracious readiness or willingness, to grant readily ’, OEDO.
Sweet: ‘Dearly loved or prized, precious’, OEDO.
Actual sin: 'Sin committed through a person's own actions; opposed to original sin', OEDO.
Repine: 'grumble, complain', OEDO.
Worm: 'A human being likened to a worm or reptile as an object of contempt, scorn, or pity; an abject, miserable creature', OEDO.
Temporals: 'Temporal things or matters', OEDO.
Sanctification: ’The action of the Holy Spirit in sanctifying or making holy the believer, by the implanting within him of the Christian graces and the destruction of sinful affections', OEDO.
Red spot: ‘Any small red lesion of the skin (as a macule, papule, etc.), esp. one forming part of a rash', OEDO.
Mourn: 'make a low inarticulate sound indicative of grief, pain, hunger, etc.; to moan', OEDO.
Sweetly: ‘In a desirable or satisfactory way’, OEDO.
Sound: ‘fainting-fit’, OEDO.
Ravish: ‘transport (a person, the mind, etc.) with the strength of some emotion; to fill with ecstasy, intense delight, or sensuous pleasure; to entrance, captivate, or enrapture’, OEDO.
Grief: ‘Hardship, suffering; a kind, or cause, of hardship or suffering’, OEDO.
Settlement: 'The act of settling property upon a person or persons', OEDO.
Portion: 'The part or share of an estate given or passing by law to an heir or other beneficiary, or to be distributed to an heir in the settlement of the estate', OEDO.
Flood: 'A popular term for uterine hæmorrhage, esp. in connection with parturition', OEDO.
Art: ‘An acquired ability of any kind; a skill at doing a specified thing, typically acquired through study and practice’, OEDO.
Fruit: 'an embryo, fœtus’, OEDO.
Quick with child: 'Pregnant with a live fetus', OEDO.
Flood: 'A popular term for uterine hæmorrhage, esp. in connection with parturition', OEDO.
Bole armeniac: 'An astringent earth brought from Armenia, and formerly used as an antidote and styptic', OEDO.
Claret: ‘a type of wine having an amber, reddish-orange, or light, clear red colour, as distinguished from both red wine and white wine’, OEDO.
Loaf sugar: 'Sugar refined and moulded into a loaf or conical mass', OEDO.
Consumption: 'abnormality or loss of humours, resulting in wasting', OEDO.
Skrike: 'A shrill cry, a screech', OEDO.
Distemper: 'Derangement or disturbance of the “humour” or ”temper”', OEDO.

Cordial: ‘A food or (esp. alcoholic) drink with medicinal or health-giving properties’, OEDO. For the use of cordials as medicine, see Elaine Leong, ‘Making Medicines in the Early Modern Household’, Bulletin of the History of Medicine 82, no. 1 (2008): 145–68.
Scurf: 'A morbid condition of the skin, esp. of the head, characterized by the separation of branny scales, without inflammation', OEDO.
Extremity: 'Extreme or inordinate intensity or violence (of passion, action, suffering, labour, etc)', OEDO.
Fain: ‘Disposed, inclined or willing, eager’, OEDO.
Keeper: ‘A nurse; one who has charge of the sick’, OEDO.
Abroad: 'openly', OEDO.
Ague: 'An acute or high fever; disease, or a disease, characterized by such fever, esp. when recurring periodically’, OEDO.
Stone: ‘A hard morbid concretion in the body, esp. in the kidney or urinary bladder, or in the gallbladder’, OEDO.
Extremity: 'Extreme or inordinate intensity or violence (of passion, action, suffering, labour, etc)', OEDO.
Understanding: 'Power or ability to understand', OEDO.
Sweetly: ‘In a desirable or satisfactory way’, OEDO.

Providence: 'The foreknowing and protective care of God (or nature, etc.); divine direction, control, or guidance', OEDO. See Alexandra Walsham, Providence in Early Modern England (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 1999).
Sweet: ‘pleasant disposition and manners’, OEDO.
Favour: 'Appearance, aspect, look', OEDO.
Phlegm: 'Mucus as produced in or eliminated from the body, esp. when excessive in quantity or abnormal in quality', OEDO.
Cast: ‘vomit’, OEDO.
Extremity: 'Extreme or inordinate intensity or violence (of passion, action, suffering, labour, etc)', OEDO.

Salvation: ‘Salvation: 'The saving of the soul; the deliverance from sin and its consequences, and admission to eternal bliss, wrought for man by the atonement of Christ', OEDO. On protestantism and salvation, see Alec Ryrie, Being Protestant in Reformation Britain (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 2013), chap. 2.
Physic: 'A medicinal substance', OEDO.
Intermitting: 'Marked by an intermission (of fever)', OEDO.
Strait: 'Of a way, passage, or channel: So narrow as to make transit difficult', OEDO.
Extremity: 'Extreme or inordinate intensity or violence (of passion, action, suffering, labour, etc.)’, OEDO.
Physic: 'A medicinal substance', OEDO.
Pearl: 'Any white lesion of the eye, esp. a corneal opacity or a cataract', OEDO.
Rub: ‘affect painfully or disagreeably’, OEDO.
Comrades: plural of comrade, ‘close companion, mate, fellow’, OEDO.
Quick with child: 'Pregnant with a live fetus ', OEDO.
Palsy: 'Paralysis or paresis (weakness) of all or part of the body, sometimes with tremor; an instance of this’, OEDO.
Physic: 'A medicinal substance', OEDO.
Michaelmas: 'The feast of St Michael (St Michael and all Angels), one of the quarter days in England, Ireland, and Wales; the date of this, 29 September', OEDO.
Intermit: 'cease or stop for a time', OEDO.

Salvation: 'The saving of the soul; the deliverance from sin and its consequences, and admission to eternal bliss, wrought for man by the atonement of Christ', OEDO. On protestantism and salvation, see Alec Ryrie, Being Protestant in Reformation Britain (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 2013), chap. 2.
Fit: ’a sudden, transient episode of fever, often with chills’, OEDO.
Travail: 'childbirth; labour', OEDO.
Reins of the back: 'The region of the kidneys', OEDO.
Mother: 'The uterus', OEDO.
Childbed: ’The state of a woman in labour, childbirth‘, OEDO.

On protestantism and salvation, see Alec Ryrie, Being Protestant in Reformation Britain (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 2013), chap. 2.

Providence: 'The foreknowing and protective care of God (or nature, etc.); divine direction, control, or guidance', OEDO. See Alexandra Walsham, Providence in Early Modern England (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 1999).
Sweet: ‘Dearly loved or prized, precious’, OEDO.
Red gum: 'A bright red, maculopapular rash seen in infants and young children, often during teething', OEDO.
Looseness: 'Laxity (of the bowels), esp. as a morbid symptom; diarrhoea', OEDO.
Sweetly: ‘In a desirable or satisfactory way’, OEDO.
Gangrene: 'a small circumscribed ulcer on the skin, esp. on the leg or in the mouth', OEDO.
Grief: ‘A bodily injury or ailment; a morbid affection of any part of the body; a sore, wound; a blemish of the skin; a disease, sickness’, OEDO.
Intermission: 'Temporary cessation, respite, relief, rest, pause’, OEDO.
Physic: 'A medicinal substance', OEDO.
Fit: ’a sudden, transient episode of fever, often with chills’, OEDO.
Grief: ‘Mental pain, distress, or sorrow’, OEDO.

Oath: ‘A solemn or formal declaration invoking God (or a god, or other object of reverence) as witness to the truth of a statement’, OEDO. On oaths and oath-taking in early modern England, see John Spurr, ‘A Profane History of Early Modern Oaths’, Transactions of the Royal Historical Society 11 (2001): 37–63.
Spleen: 'A grudge’, OEDO.
Unhandsomely: ‘Discourteously, rudely’, OEDO.
Abroad: 'openly', OEDO.

Salvation: ‘Salvation: 'The saving of the soul; the deliverance from sin and its consequences, and admission to eternal bliss, wrought for man by the atonement of Christ', OEDO. On protestantism and salvation, see Alec Ryrie, Being Protestant in Reformation Britain (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 2013), chap. 2.
Redeemed: 'Of a person, a soul, etc.: saved or delivered from sin, damnation, or criminality', OEDO.
Grief: ‘Hardship, suffering; a kind, or cause, of hardship or suffering’, OEDO.
Endeavoured: ’make a (hostile) attempt upon; to attack', OEDO.
Blaze: ‘decry, defame, hold up to infamy’, OEDO.
Abroad: 'openly', OEDO.
Plausible: ‘Acceptable, agreeable, pleasing, gratifying’, OEDO.
Carriage: 'A person's habitual behaviour or conduct, viewed as a sign of his or her character;a person's demeanour or manners', OEDO.
Settlement: 'The act of settling property upon a person or persons; the particular terms of such an arrangement; the deed or instrument by which it is effected', OEDO.

Providence: 'The foreknowing and protective care of God (or nature, etc.); divine direction, control, or guidance', OEDO. See Alexandra Walsham, Providence in Early Modern England (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 1999).
Friend: 'A close relation, a kinsman or kinswoman', OEDO.
Regeneration: 'The period of Christ's teaching ministry on earth', OEDO.
Lathe: 'A barn', OEDO.
Mow: 'A place in a barn where hay or corn is heaped up', OEDO.
Light: ‘descend (esp. by flying, falling, jumping, etc.), and land or settle in a place or on a surface’, OEDO.
Pathetical: ‘Expressing or arising from passion or strong emotion; passionate, emotional; earnest’, OEDO.
Temporal: ‘Secular as opposed to sacred’, OEDO.
Grief: ‘Mental pain, distress, or sorrow’, OEDO.
Calumny: ‘A false charge or imputation, intended to damage another's reputation; a slanderous ’, OEDO.
Extremity: 'Extreme or inordinate intensity or violence (of passion, action, suffering, labour, etc)', OEDO.
Grief: ‘Mental pain, distress, or sorrow’, OEDO.
Mother: 'The uterus', OEDO.
Grief: ‘A morbid affection of any part of the body; a sore, wound’, OEDO.
Subtlety: ‘A cunning or crafty scheme … a trick; a clever stratagem’, OEDO.
Dissemble: ‘put on a feigned or false appearance of; to feign, pretend, simulate', OEDO.
Smitten: ‘strike or hit (a person or thing), usually forcefully', OEDO.
Condole: ‘grieve with; to express sympathy with another in his affliction’, OEDO.
Cordial: 'Heartfelt, hearty; sincere, genuine; thoroughly committed to a course of action or a cause', OEDO.
Candour: ‘Freedom from malice, favourable disposition, kindliness’, OEDO.
Grief: ‘Hardship, suffering; a kind, or cause, of hardship or suffering’, OEDO.
Cross: ‘misfortune, adversity’, OEDO.
Repine: 'grumble, complain', OEDO.
Recruit: ‘recuperate, recover’, OEDO.
Grief: ‘Mental pain, distress, or sorrow’, OEDO.
Adventure: ‘Any undertaking the outcome of which is uncertain; an experiment; a test of luck’, OEDO.
Discreetly: ‘with discretion; prudently', OEDO.
Withal: ‘therewith’, OEDO.
Sweet: ‘Dearly loved or prized, precious’, OEDO.
Extremity: 'Extreme or inordinate intensity or violence (of passion, action, suffering, labour, etc.)', OEDO.
Withal: ‘therewith’, OEDO.
Consummate: ‘bring to completion; to finish’, OEDO.
Sanctification: 'The action of the Holy Spirit in sanctifying or making holy the believer, by the implanting within him of the Christian graces and the destruction of sinful affections’, OEDO.
My think: ‘it seems to me’, OEDO.
Cross: ‘misfortune, adversity’, OEDO.
Incomprehensible: ‘That cannot be contained or circumscribed within limits; illimitable, boundless, infinite; immense’, OEDO.
Repine: ‘grumble, complain', OEDO.

Salvation: 'The saving of the soul; the deliverance from sin and its consequences, and admission to eternal bliss, wrought for man by the atonement of Christ', OEDO. On protestantism and salvation, see Alec Ryrie, Being Protestant in Reformation Britain (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 2013), chap. 2.
Grief: ‘Mental pain, distress, or sorrow’, OEDO.

Salvation: 'The saving of the soul; the deliverance from sin and its consequences, and admission to eternal bliss, wrought for man by the atonement of Christ', OEDO. On protestantism and salvation, see Alec Ryrie, Being Protestant in Reformation Britain (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 2013), chap. 2.
Trinity: 'The three “persons” or modes of being of the Godhead as conceived in orthodox Christian belief; the Father, Son, and Holy Spirit as constituting one God', OEDO.
Temporal: ‘Secular as opposed to sacred’, OEDO.
Filial: 'Of sentiments, duty, etc.: Due from a child to a parent', OEDO.

Old Adam: i.e., Adam [and Eve], as opposed to Christ the ‘second Adam’. On the first and second Adam in early modern theology, see Willem J. van Asselt, ‘Christ, Predestination, and Covenant in Post-Reformation Reformed Theology’, The Oxford Handbook of Early Modern Theology 1600-1800 (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 2016), 223. [is this a gloss or a note?]
Posterity: 'The descendants collectively of any person(or, in extended use, any living thing); all who are descended from a common ancestor', OEDO.
Trinity: 'The three “persons” or modes of being of the Godhead as conceived in orthodox Christian belief; the Father, Son, and Holy Spirit as constituting one God', OEDO.
Distemper: 'Derangement or disturbance of the “humour” or “temper”', OEDO.
Latest: 'Last, final', OEDO.
Art: ‘An acquired ability of any kind; a skill at doing a specified thing, typically acquired through study and practice’, OEDO.
Frame: ‘The physical body, esp. that of a human being, usually with reference to its build or constitution; physique’, OEDO.
Sweet: ‘Gentle, easy’, OEDO.

Dying upwards: early modern medicine held that that spirits and organs rose within the body during illness or other bodily change. See Michael Stolberg, ‘Emotions and the Body in Early Modern Medicine’, Emotion Review 11, no. 2 (2019): 113.
Forenoon: 'The portion of the day before noon', OEDO.
Sweetly: ‘In a desirable or satisfactory way’, OEDO.
Physic: 'A medicinal substance', OEDO.
Videlicet: 'That is to say', OEDO.
Alley: ‘Any of the more or less linear areas into which a large church is divided; spec. one extending parallel to the main body of the church’, OEDO.
Sweet: ‘Dearly loved or prized, precious’, OEDO.
Damask: ‘The colour of the damask rose', OEDO.
Poetaster: 'An inferior poet; a writer of poor or trashy verse; a mere versifier', OEDO.
Sweet: ‘pleasant disposition and manners’, OEDO.
Philistine: 'A member of a non-Semitic people occupying the southern coast of Palestine in biblical times, who came into conflict with the Israelites during the 12th and 11th centuries b.c.', OEDO.
Travail: 'hardship, suffering … trouble, difficulty', OEDO. .

Salvation: ‘The saving of the soul; the deliverance from sin and its consequences, and admission to eternal bliss, wrought for man by the atonement of Christ', OEDO. On protestantism and salvation, see Alec Ryrie, Being Protestant in Reformation Britain (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 2013), chap. 2.
Withal: ‘Along with the rest; in addition’, OEDO.
Catholic: ‘Complete or without exception’, OEDO.
Sustentation: ‘Patience, forbearance', OEDO.
Sanctification: ’The action of the Holy Spirit in sanctifying or making holy the believer, by the implanting within him of the Christian graces and the destruction of sinful affections', OEDO.
Incomprehensible: 'That cannot be contained or circumscribed within limits; illimitable, boundless, infinite; immense’, OEDO.
Trinity: 'The three “persons” or modes of being of the Godhead as conceived in orthodox Christian belief; the Father, Son, and Holy Spirit as constituting one God', OEDO.
Videlicet: 'That is to say', OEDO.
Raw-boned: 'having projecting bones barely covered with flesh; extremely lean or gaunt', OEDO.
Tumult: ‘A disorderly crowd, a mob’, OEDO.

Providence: 'The foreknowing and protective care of God (or nature, etc.); divine direction, control, or guidance', OEDO. See Alexandra Walsham, Providence in Early Modern England (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 1999).
Childbed: 'The bed in which a child is born', OEDO.
Grief: ‘Mental pain, distress, or sorrow’, OEDO.
Couch: 'A frame or structure, with what is spread over it (or simply a layer of some soft substance), on which to lie down for rest or sleep; a bed’, OEDO.
Extremity: 'Extreme or inordinate intensity or violence (of passion, action, suffering, labour, etc.)', OEDO.
Childbed: ’The state of a woman in labour, childbirth‘, OEDO.
Child wife: 'A woman in labour, or who has recently given birth', OEDO.
Grief: ‘Mental pain, distress, or sorrow’, OEDO.

Venturous: ‘Disposed to venture upon or undertake something of a dangerous or risky nature; willing to take risks or incur danger; bold, daring, or enterprising in action or opinion; adventurous, venturesome', OEDO.
Resolution: 'Determination; firmness or steadfastness of purpose', OEDO.
Divine: ‘A theologian', OEDO.
Sequestration: 'The appropriation of the income of a property in order to satisfy claims against the owner', OEDO.
Bailiff: 'An officer of justice under a sheriff, who executes writs and processes, distrains, and arrests’, OEDO.
Distrain: ‘constrain or force (a person) by the seizure and detention of a chattel or thing; to punish by such seizure and detention for the non-performance of such obligation', OEDO.
Assignment: 'Legal transference of a right or property', OEDO.

Mitigation: 'abatement or relaxation of the severity or rigour of a law, penalty, etc.; extenuation or palliation of an offence, fault, etc.; abatement or minimization of the loss or damage resulting from a wrongful act', OEDO.
Bailiff: 'An officer of justice under a sheriff, who executes writs and processes, distrains, and arrests’, OEDO.
Grief: ‘Hardship, suffering; a kind, or cause, of hardship or suffering’, OEDO.

Providence: 'The foreknowing and protective care of God (or nature, etc.); divine direction, control, or guidance', OEDO. See Alexandra Walsham, Providence in Early Modern England (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 1999).
Portion: 'The part or share of an estate given or passing by law to an heir or other beneficiary, or to be distributed to an heir in the settlement of the estate', OEDO.
Ravish: ‘drag off or carry away (a woman) by force or with violence (occasionally also implying subsequent rape).’ OEDO.
Poor: ‘unfortunate, wretched’, OEDO.
